Key Match Events: Anthony Volpe’s grand slam put the Yankees in front 5-2, their first lead since the 10th inning of Game 1.
Yankees rookie Austin Wells hit a solo homer in the sixth inning.
Five Yankees relievers combined for five scoreless innings while allowing just one hit.
Freddie Freeman’s fourth home run of the series gave the Dodgers a 2-0 lead in the first inning.
Yankees closer Luke Weaver struck out Mookie Betts in the seventh inning.
The Yankees’ five-run eighth inning extended their lead.
Mark Leiter Jr. struck out Shohei Ohtani with a 3-2 splitter in the seventh inning.
Pre-Game Insights: The Yankees will turn to ace Gerrit Cole for Game 5, while the Dodgers will counter with Jack Flaherty.
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts was able to rest his 'A' bullpen for Game 5.
Post-Match Reflections: Yankees closer Luke Weaver described the victory as 'Pretty. Monumentally. Huge.'
Yankees reliever Clay Holmes emphasized the importance of the victory and the momentum it could build.
Anthony Volpe reflected on his grand slam, saying he 'blacked out right when it went out.'
Jazz Chisholm Jr. discussed the Yankees’ new mantra: 'We love making history.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Yankees fans were ejected for prying open Mookie Betts’ glove during the game.
Dodgers starting pitcher Ben Casparius commented on the fan interference play involving Mookie Betts.
Yankees third baseman Jazz Chisholm Jr. mentioned the team's desire to make history by coming back in the series.
